item.description:
One in a series of sixteen Flipsiders games designed to resemble pastel colored audio cassettes. The game contained a metal gameboard that would flip out with the snap of the wrist. A storage compartment at the top of the game would hold the magnetic pawns. A spring-loaded switch would spin the wheels of the cassette to generate random numbers and events during play. The game would hang from a blister pack on display at the store.

Players take turns using the right spinner to advance their board marker. When a player reaches a jump, the player must use the left spinner to determine if the jump is successful. The winner is the first player to complete all four rounds of the steeplechase.

One in a series of sixteen Flipsiders games designed to resemble pastel colored audio cassettes. The game contained a metal gameboard that would flip out with the snap of the wrist. A storage compartment at the top of the game would hold the magnetic pawns. A spring-loaded switch would spin the wheels of the cassette to generate random numbers and events during play. The game would hang from a blister pack on display at the store.

The left spinner is used to indicate upstream and downstream movement. The right spinner is used to indicate distance moved. The first player to reach the finish line is the winner.

name.value: Sweet and Sour: The Chinese Restaurant Game

item.description: A dexterity game that requires the players to use chopsticks to move small pieces around.

BLOODBATH simulates the horrific, turning point, battle in the Greek attack towards Ankara in August, 1921. The Greek Army had been unstoppable up to now and the Turks were reeling back to the last stand defenses in the hills just across the Sakarya River. Their morale had taken a serious blow, so serious, that orders were to shoot any Turk soldier caught fleeing during the battle. The Greeks paused for two weeks before advancing across the river, giving the Turks time to build a two lines of defenses. Greek divisions averaged 10,000 men, while Turk divisions averaged 5000. Both sides were feeling the pinch of supply issues, both quite determined to crush the other. If the Greeks won, Ankara, Turkey's new capitol, would fall and perhaps part of Turkey would become part of Greece. The battle and war all reached this pivotal situation, critical to both sides. It would be bloody--over 18,000 died on the hills from August 23 to 30.

Game scale: 12 hr. turns, battalions. Each hex is around 400 yds. Owners of The Great Attack 1922 will easily assimilate the rules, although there are some new ones to learn.

The game comes with one 11x17 inch map, 280 counters and rulebook.

Related game:
Bir Buyuk Turk Saldiri

Bumper Car Arena is OGP's first full blown board game. Earlier offerings were more along the Cheapass Game quality of components. In this game, the components are quite good. This is a race game with pre-programmed movement ala Roborally. Players also score points for knocking into their opponents. The last place player also controls the "rogue" bumper car, Jimmy Fudge -- who only wants to bump other players.

Each player controls one bumper car. Simultaneous movement card play determines the movement order. Players score points for moving around the track in the appropriate direction, and for bumping other bumper cars. Draws are done from a face up draft of n+1 cards where n is the number of players. The remaining card is used to control Jimmy Fudge's bumper car. Play continues until someone has scored 21 points, thereafter, there is an increasing chance of the game ending every turn.

From the Publisher:

It's a beautiful day at the amusement park. You and your friends have decided to take over the bumper car ride for your own purposes. Players score points for bumping other players cars and going around the track in the proper direction. (Going backwards makes the carnies angry.) And who is this Jimmy Fudge kid anyway?

item.description: A simple spin and move game on the Mississippi River. The speedboat pieces are kind of nice, but the massive, upright roulette style spinner is the highlight of the game.

This edition of the popular trivia game has cool retro packaging and 2400 trivia questions in six categories to take you back to the colorful 80s! Includes 4 collectible tokens based on 80s icons. For 2-4 players or teams.

Categories in this edition are headlines, television, movies, music, sports & leisure, and wild card.

item.description:
Very closely related to What's That on My Head?, and Hedbanz for Adults!.

The object is to guess your celebrity name first and win the game. Your celebrity name is in a card in a headband that is placed on your head.

The play - first, you wear a headband that has a randomly selected celebrity name card inserted into the slot. The oldest player then spins the spinner and moves his meeple to the appropriate position on the board. If you land on the "ask a question" space, you get to ask the other players a yes/no question about the celebrity name on your head. If you get it right, you get to spin again. If not, the play moves clockwise. There is a space for asking two questions, losing a turn or receiving a "big hint". The player reads the "big hint" question on the card and the group is allowed to respond beyond yes/no. The player then ends his turn.

If you guess your celebrity name wrong, you still get to keep on playing, you place a new, random celebrity name into your headband.

There are also blank cards so you can write in other people's names who may only be celebrities in your world.

item.description:
Hunters in the Sky is a complete miniatures game of WWII air combat. The basic rules allow for relatively large battles with up to a dozen aircraft per side and minimal record keeping.

Optional rules are included which cover; air to ground combat, bombers (dive, level and torpedo), variable pilot quality and experience, and simple campaign system.

Advanced rules which add realism include; advanced maneuvering, deflection shooting, visual spotting, limited ammunition, critical damage, and more...

Also included is the Warbirds aircraft lists, with game stats for 118 different aircraft from 10 different nations.
28 pages.

"Hunters in the sky is by far the best WWII aircraft game I have ever played! If you do not have this in your collection then SHAME ON YOU! BUY IT NOW!" - R.A. June 2006

Download version can be purchased at www.wargamedownloads.com

Counter-Terrorist Warfare in the Modern Age

Special Forces is a miniatures game of close combat in the modern era. Inspired by first-person shooter computer games such as Delta Force and Rainbow Six, he rules are designed for small scale battles with one or two dozen figures per side.

Special Forces is easy to learn and fast playing, with an emphasis on playability. It includes rules for infantry action and vehicles and comes with two sample scenarios; Columbian Crack-Down and Hostage Rescue - Iraq.

13 pages

Download version can be found at www.wargamedownloads.com

From Dr. Toy:

"There are 1,200 questions included in this innovative game. It is available in French and English. This game is perfect for children 6 and over. There are three questions on each card: one is aimed at younger children (6-7 yrs.) the second aimed for older(8-9 yrs) and the third aimed for 10 to 12 years old children. Everyone at all ages can play the game together. The first player or team to complete the jigsaw puzzle wins. Most questions are based on actual school textbooks."

Expanded by:

 McWiz Junior Booster Bus: The Bus of Knowledge in Math

item.description:
From Discovery Toys:

"Pizza parts make a "whole" lot of fun. Help children visualize and understand the concept of fractions, using a favorite food and a fun strategy game. Game variations challenge players to master fraction equivalencies, addition and more."

From the Publisher's Website at http://www.hyperion-games.com/dil01.html **
 


"The Dilbert Principle:
The most ineffective workers are systematically moved to the place where they can do the least damage: management.

Welcome to the absurdities of the business world: a place of rightsizing, vision statements, bungee bosses, peer reviews, total quality management and team-building exercises; a place where millennia of evolution is put to use in the struggle for the best cubicle and competition over office furniture.

In Dilbert™ the Board Game you and up to five friends toil in an office of evil HR directors, accounting trolls, canine consultants, and a boss who bears a suspicious resemblance to the devil. Every project assigned to you is doomed from the start, so your best bet is to dump it on someone else or try to get it killed before it eats away any more of your life. In fact, the only thing that really matters in the end is your own happiness. So why bother with work?

Dilbert™ is a hilarious board game for 3-6 players ages 14 and up, and requires about 90 minutes to play. "

item.description:
The theme

On a beach in St Tropez, some celebrities are having a nude midnight swim. But the paparazzi are here! It's a mad scramble to find your clothes in the dark before the flashes of the cameras.

				
					The game

Each player is one of 8 possible celebrities. All the clothes and accessories of the celebrities are shuffled and dealt out on the table. You have a few moments to memorize the positions of the clothes before the lights are switched off.

In the dark, the icons in the corner of the cards glow. You can tell its a pair of underpants, but whose shoes are they? You can switch around the cards to try to confuse the other players. At any moment, anyone could switch on the lights and then it's "freeze!" as the celebrities' pictures are splashed across the front page of every gossip magazine.

You get "embarrassment" points for being naked, or for wearing someone else's clothes.

item.description:
The first matching game using wildlife photos which were taken directly from DK's best selling children's books.

Classic bingo is only one of the variations which are described in the rules pamphlet, as young players are challenged to work on matching, sorting, and language skills

A perfect first game for the children...

name.value: Ne t'en fais pas!: Jeu de cartes

item.description:
Card version roughly simulating the endgame situation in vanilla "Mens erger je niet!" / "Ne t'en fais pas!" (a "Pachisi" / "Parcheesi" clone), the object being to 'bring the pawns home'.

Each player has an identical pack of 24 cards, in one of 4 colors. There are 4 sets of 6 cards with each set having a die value printed on the cards: 1 through 4. The cards within a set have a number of colored pawns on them, 1 through 6, and have to be played onto their 'home' pile in that order.

The object is to play out all your cards onto the 4 'home' piles while hampering your opponent.

Card play is done "Shut the box" style, where the eyes on a standard D6 determine the total value of cards that may be played onto their 'home' piles. A [6] rolled allows for another die roll and play of cards.
The pawns printed on the cards come into play when hampering the opponent. When one of the 'home' piles -represented by the dice- reaches the same size -represented by the pawns- as the opponent's identical pile, the opponent has to empty that 'home' pile.

Winner is the player who 'brings all pawns home' first.

From the Rules of Play:

STARGO is a fun and engaging way to introduce kids to the basic concepts of stars, galaxies and constellations. There are two ways to play, and both are based on Bingo. Version "A" uses basic number and color concepts as players search for stars on one constellation. Version "B" uses basic visual and memory skills as players enjoy traditional Bingo on a grid featuring 24 constellations.

				
					

Version A:

There are 30 large glossy cards, each featuring a constellation with numbered, colored stars (that glow in the dark!). Each player selects one. Colored and numbered stars are selected from the bag and called -- first to complete his constellation wins.

Version B:

On the flip side of the constellation cards is a traditional Bingo grid of constellations. Constellations are selected from a deck (each has information about that constellation on the back). First to complete five in a row wins.

				
					

The constellation cards feature glow in the dark stars and an orienting arrow. Combined with the included compass, they can be used to help find those constellations in the night sky. The smaller cards contain facts about the constellations and the stars within them. The rulebook also contains information about stargazing.

One in a series of sixteen Flipsiders games designed to resemble pastel colored audio cassettes. The game contained a metal gameboard that would flip out with the snap of the wrist. A storage compartment at the top of the game would hold the magnetic pawns. A spring-loaded switch would spin the wheels of the cassette to generate random numbers and events during play. The game would hang from a blister pack on display at the store.

The spinners determine how far one may move during one’s turn. The players will compete in three races and the first to complete all three races is the winner.

Die Angelschlacht (the pivotal battle) 1944 covers the 25th SS PG\12SS Panzer division's counterattack on June 7th against the strung out Canadian forces west of Caen. The 12thSS struck with 45 tanks and quickly advanced causing a panic to the allies. The Canadians had little armor and were out of artillery range. The battle lasted 6 hours and the SS advanced only a few miles but this attack delayed the allied advance for another 30 days! The game has over 280 counters and one 11x17" map, rulebook. Include in the game are unique random events that makes game play never the same. For those interested in historical or what games, player's may choose to do either. The game contains many scenarios.

Each hex is 200-250 yds, each turn is 30 min. Units are company level, each with a morale and movement rating. Actual fire strengths depend on the unit firing, type of attack, range to target, and weapon firing. New rules cover random events, anti-aircraft fire, air units, M10's, Panther tanks.

name.value: The Dvina River Offensive: Final Blows in North Russia, August 1919

item.description:
By August 1919, the British 45th and 46th Battalions, together with over seven river monitors and gunboats mounting up to 9" guns, over 25 aircraft (mostly DH9A bombers) were in place for the final blow on the Red virus known as Bolshevism. By this time, the French and Americans had all left. It was now a British show and one that was destined to leave a bloody nose upon the Reds. At least that was the plan! As the troops gathered along both sides of the Dvina River (the river was very large), the opposing forces were as determined. The Reds fielded the 3rd Brigade\18th Division amounting to the 160, 161, 162 Regiments, numerous large artillery barges, six fighter aircraft, many gunboats, lots of mines, trenches. The overconfident British had not factored in the effects of Mother Nature, which as the battle wore on, smiled too often on the Red forces. Clearing BOTH sides of this major river ( think Mississippi) and advancing hundreds of miles to Kotlas (the main Red base) in hindsight, seemed like a crazy idea, but at the time, was a tempting objective. And so it was. The Dvina River Offensive had it all: dogfighting aircraft, ground combat, naval surface action, naval bombardment, bombing, machine guns, artillery, river monitors and gunboats, unpredictable river currents, water levels, sandbars, floating mines sent down by the Reds, foul weather, balloons. The offensive lasted four days. One part went extraordinarily well-another part nosedived into hell-both sides get to enjoy this game!

Game scale is 750 yds a hex, turns are 12 hrs, 10 in all. Ground units are platoons, artillery batteries, single aircraft include: Sopwith, Spad, Avro, DH9A, Re 8, Neuiport, M20 and Short. River ships include: monitors, gunboats, each representing one ship. Ground units include Lewis guns, MG, Stokes mortars, leaders, infantry. There are two game maps, one covers the ground action and the other the air to air combat at a different scale (50 yd a hex). Aircraft are rated for speed, bombing, size, maneuver, altitude. Thus, the game is really two games: an operational ground game, a tactical naval and air to air combat game!

Rare German Space Battle System based on the famous German Sci-Fi Novels.

German box text: "Wollten Sie schon immer einmal hinter dem Kommandopult des Schlachtschiffes STARDUST Platz nehmen und den Stolz der terranischen Raumflotte persönlich ins Gefecht führen? Jetzt ist es möglich........

Als erstes einer Reihe von Spielen mit dem Hintergrund der weltbekannten Perry Rhodan-Serie erhältlich - das Raumkampfsystem! Ein neuartiges, leicht zu handhabendes Regelsystem ermöglicht eine "realistische" und detailgetreue Simulation von Geschehnissen, wie sie für ein Gefecht in den endlosen Weiten des Weltraums typisch sind. Ob zwei einzelne Raumer ein Duell miteinander ausfechten oder ganze Verbände aufeinander prallen sollen, können Sie selbst entscheiden, und auch sonst sind Sie es, der die Entscheidungen trifft..

Taktische Bewegung, Abbremsen oder Beschleunigen, Kurztransition oder Notsprung, Salven, Punktfeuer oder volle Breitseite, alles lieggt in Ihrer Hand. Als Spielmaterial steht Ihnen dabei eine Spielfläche von 59 x 42 cm, ein Regelband, ein Szenarioband, ein Satz Datenblätter, 56 Seiten Hintergrundmaterial, 180 Spielsteine und zwei zwanzigseitige Würfel zur Verfügung."

Add-Ons were: 
- Das Combatsystem
- Protektorat von Norgas
- Das Solare Imperium
- Die Raumflotte der Druuf
- Die Raumflotte der Maahks I
- Die Raumflotte der Terraner II
- Die Raumflotte von Alt-Arkon 
- Arkon's Robotflotte
- Der topsidische Gila-Kreuzer
- Die terranische Kaulquappe
- Pedlar - Handelsraumer der Springer
- Spezialkreuzer California
- Roboter

From the website:

The goal of War on Terror, the boardgame is to liberate the world, ridding it of fear and terrorism forever. Naturally, only the biggest and strongest Empires are up to this task and so a certain amount of dominance needs to be proved. Alternatively, you can play as the terrorists, fighting for a world without empires.

Everyone starts the game as an Empire, with a couple of free villages and they can settle anywhere in the world. Although peaceful (we had to ban fighting in the first round) the 'politics' of the game already start to form, depending on what oil is discovered and how 'aggressive' the initial settlement choice is.

Empires then spread over the planet grabbing all available land, searching for the best oil and the most strategic borders. Some go for towns and cities, other spend their cash on extra empire cards, building up their political options. Maybe, if they're lucky, they'll get an early nuke.

Sooner or later someone takes a pop. Maybe the Axis of Evil has declared an Empire evil, giving them a few terrorist cards which are just too tempting not to play. Maybe someone is looking too strong already. Maybe you've got a grudge from a previous game or maybe you just want to win. Either way, war is declared or the terrorists strike!

Although it is possible to win the game with all the players still playing as Empires, the more likely outcome is that Empires are destroyed, bankrupted, or simply cave in and become terrorist players. As more empires fall they work together as a single terrorist player. With each new influx of terrorist cards and cash for the terrorist cause, the remaining Empires begin to wish that maybe they shouldn't have funded quite so much terrorism as they did.

item.description: Switch is the first of the small box games published by Pseudon and is noted with "#1" on the spine. The game includes 16 tiles which are first laid out for all to see. The tiles are then flipped, and in turn a player must flip two to find the scoring combinations on the score sheet. The winner of the game is the first to make all the combinations on their score sheet.

"A New Twist to the Popular Card Game Hearts!" boasts the cover. In fact, the game is essentially Hearts with a retirement theme. There are 40 cards, 10 each in 4 suits. The black & white artwork on each card depicts various advantages to retirement (more time, relaxation, etc.) The lead player lays down a card. Players must follow suit if possible. High card in the suit led takes the trick and that player lays the next card. The person with the least points at the end of the game is the winner. The cards are packed in a box that could easily hold nine times as many.

item.description: Captain Morgan's Wrath is the pirate drinking game by Party Hard Corps. Spinning a tee-totum (think a dreidel), the players are encouraged to be as loud with their yaaaaars as possible while the it spins, or even bang on the table to try to make a player "walk the plank!" First player with five doubloons and the captain's patch is the commodore, and the winner- unless the crew mutinies, and leaves that land lubber on an uncharted island!

item.description: Cult: The Drinking Game of Politics in an Esoteric Order is the first game by Party Hard Corps. The players take on the roles of cultists in an occult group, vying for political influence on their way to illumination. One player, the Messiah- whose signifying ring could be passed on at any turn- gets to declare what the cult worships (and therefore what rules are in play). A party game of fast drinking and fast dice rolling.

Players begin with 4,000 dollars and have the chance to make a fortune or go broke by investing in farms and farm related businesses. A property can be purchased only by landing on it and each time a player must decide whether to invest his limited funds or to hope for something better among the 28 farms and 9 businesses available along the track. Cheaper properties are easier to develop but have a smaller payoff when landed on by an opponent. (just like Monopoly). Another decision must be made regarding the 3 different kinds of crops that may be planted on each farm. Again cheaper pays off sooner but in smaller amounts. Once the crop is in a player can add farm equipment in the form of plastic "silo sections" which are piled in strict color sequence. Limited quantities of the best crops and the highest silo section adds to the decision making process. A player may mortgage a property to pay debt or to make other investments and can still collect 10% of his normal fee from a visiting opponent. Other features include taxes, becoming incorporated, luck cards which can be disastrous, selling properties to an opponent or the treasury.

From Dr. Toy

"This game incorporates the traditional Scrabble Jr. game, but is played like a crossword puzzle, featuring baby animals and wildlife found in National Parks. Kid-sized words and colorful pictures of animals make it fun to match letter tiles to words on two playful crossword grids. One side features wildlife, while the other side features the environment included is an endangered animal coloring book featuring facts about endangered wildlife."

This game features 96 "domino" tiles, consisting of different pairings of the 12 zodiac symbols. Each symbol appears red and black. Twelve of the tiles have stars at one end and are "wild". 2 to 4 players play, each using a rack of 6 tiles. Tiles can be placed anywhere in the layout provided that they match the same symbol in opposite color of at least one face that has been previously played. Notches on the tiles help keep the layout securely in place. The score for a play depends on the number of matches which, in rare cases, can be as many as 6. If a player can make a match on at least one face of his tile he may play a second or third and so on up to all 6 tiles from his hand. Play ends when, after all the tiles have been drawn a player clears his rack, earning a bonus. High score wins

Inspiration is one of Wolfgang Kramer’s not so well-known games, which he designed together with his wife Ursula. It is a party game in the vein of Taboo or Activity, although the players do not paraphrase terms or play charades. Rather, the players try to solve picture puzzles faster than their opponents. In each round, one of the players acts as the moderator and chooses two picture cards, that together represent a two part noun (e.g. ball game (cards 73 and 20) or treasure chamber (cards 54 and 104)). The player may choose between asking an easy, medium or difficult question. Then the other players try to solve the puzzle, while a sand timer runs down. Depending on the difficulty, the player who calls out the correct answer first, may advance 2, 3, or 4 spaces on the track. The first player to reach the goal is the winner. 
Inspiration features a clever card index box, to keep the picture cards organized and two bookmarks to quickly find where to put back the previously selected cards.

item.description:
“Millennium – the millennium game” (as it would be literally - and rather silly - translated into English) is a memory game with a twist meets a historical trivia game. The game board shows an event, an important person or anything characteristic for each decade from 10 to 2000 (with the exception of 500, 1000 and 1500) represented in nice comic art as well as text and arranged in a huge spiral covering almost the complete board.
At the beginning of the game, the players cover 10 of the decades one by one with cardboard disks numbered from 1 to 10, while reading out the year and the accompanying text. E.g. “10 Emperor Augustus”, “1060 William the Conqueror”, “1190 The third Crusade” or “1770 The USA”. 
Each player then gets ten transparent plastic chips. The goal of the game is to get rid of these chips by correctly remembering the events etc. under the numbered cardboard disks. In each turn, initially the player rolls a d12. Then he has to repeat the decade and the text under the corresponding disk. Only if he succeeds, he may return one chip to the box and replace the disk on a new decade; in any case, the next player gets to roll the die. The 11 and 12 on the die have special functions:
When rolling 11, the player may place one of his chips on a cardboard disk of his choice. The next player who rolls the corresponding number has to take this chip before trying to remember what is underneath.
When rolling 12, the player asks the player with the most chips left to remember what is under a disk of his choice. If the other player succeeds, he may place one of his chips on the disk and replace the disk, otherwise, the first player has to solve the task. If he does not succeed either, the player with the most chips may give him one of his chips.
Apart from the material described, Millennium contains a small almanac (30 pg.) with a short description of each decades event, person etc.

Script is the third of the small box games published by Pseudon and is noted with "#3" on the spine, and it is a word game. The game consists of a set of letter tiles each with a number, as in Scrabble. The unique thing about the game is that over the course of the game players must come up with 20 words each beginning with a different letter of the alphabet, and all the words must be different.

Opus is the third of the larger box games published by Pseudon. It is a musical game where players must match cards showing styles of music in the right combinations to score points. The board is quite nice-looking with spaces for cards on the top and musical staffs below that identify the combinations to be made.

item.description: Old Lord Humbug is rich. More than 600 years of thriftiness and savings in the family has left the Lord with considerable property, stocks, many family heirlooms and 100 million English pounds that will be distributed to the family members when the Lord dies. However, all of the heirs have already waited a very long time: the old Lord refuses to die! He is already 86 and could live another 100 years! The possible heirs are: the sparing sister Lady Scrape Humbug, the poor old friend of the family Sir Humpty, Trickenham the butler, Miss Fuzzy the careless daughter, Spoiler Humbug the prodigal son, and Vanity the ambitious mistress. They each try in every way possible to influence the old man, in an effort to win the him over and get the inheritance for themselves. Players in this game take the part of these heirs are.

Track-Gammon is a backgammon-like game. Each player has five pieces of different sizes; the pieces must move out of the start in increasing order of size, but must enter the goal space in decreasing order of size.

Subsidie is a quick card game for 3 to 6 players and the players try to win projects with government grants. In addition several obstacles must be overcome: grants can be lost, somebody else can take over the project, the project can fail due to scandal... The purpose of the play is to apply enough government funds as possible for the realization of projects. The winner is who at the end of the play has applied the largest amount subsidy for realized projects.

ConXion is an abstract game using hexagonal tiles. The game is primarily for three players (it can also be played by two or six). The object is to connect the opposing sides of the board in your color with the center. Tiles must be placed so they connect to the center. Instead of placing one of their tiles, a player can rotate anyone's tile, which can change the connectivity considerably.

Captain John is always busy sailing his ship transporting goods from far and wide. This is no easy task, because sometimes the parcels are long and thin, sometimes they have lots of corners or they are simply round. Now and then a great wave splashes onto the ship and sweeps a chest overboard. However, it is sometimes possible for the captain to fish the chest back on board again. If he maneuvers his ship well, the captain will manage to get all the goods to their destination safe and sound.

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

You are one of the notorious pirates of the Santy Anno, the terrifying three-master that makes the Caribbean seas insecure. After a long night drinking rum and partying, you have forgotten where your ship is and, even worse, who is your captain!

To resolve this, actually very common problem in a pirate’s life, the pirate’s guild has initiated a new tradition: the first 3 on board will respectively become captain and first mates. The ones arriving too late will be demoted to ship’s boys and spend the rest of the trip cleaning the deck!

Will you be fast and smart enough to avoid being spending the rest of your time with brush and bucket instead of sword and gun?

Avoid to be demoted and get a maximum of ducats. At the end of the game (5 rounds) the player with the most money is nominated captain and wins. The next 2 are his first mates. The others lose and have to pay for the next round… and to clean the table and glasses!

This is a pirate game. The 500 first copies will come with a limited Ex-ludis signed by the designer along with the expansion Santy Anno: Blackbeard at the Pub.

Expanded by:

 Santy Anno: Blackbeard at the Pub

item.description:
Players attempt to build the most successful factory to produce the best products by connecting input and output reservoirs smartly to your machines to build the most profitable factory!

Players each start with a unique empty factory floor with a support pillar in the middle. During the game you purchase machines to place in your factory. Each machine takes 1 to 3 inputs from reservoirs (yellow, blue, red, and brown) and produces one output (of the same colors, or black end products). You must always connect all reservoirs and machines correctly by using the connectors (the pipelines). At the start this is easy, but becomes more puzzling during the game.

Players start with one of each color reservoir, and can sometimes acquire additional reservoirs. On the machine-tiles you see the revenue of each machine. Connecting machines to each other (input on output) makes more advanced products which brings extra profit. But building connectors and reservoirs costs money and you must try to have the most money at the end.

It was originally published by Cwali for 2-4 players, and later reprinted by Z-Man in a larger box with components for 2-5 players.

				
					Cwali edition (2006)

Contents: 4 factories - 48 machines - 47 reservoirs - 129 connectors - 4 relief pillars - 4 colored discs - 25 transparent discs - 1 money track

Artwork: Marco Jeurissen

From BoardgameNews:

The number of players is listed as 2-4(+) - the "+" means you can use additional copies of the game to add players (four more for each additional copy). Cwali's website for the game provides a fifth player board. The website also offers a solitaire variant of the game.

				
					Z-Man edition (2010)

Contents: 5 factories (double sided original/expert) - 55 machines; includes Factory Fun Expansion 1
Artwork: Karim Chakroun, Franck Moutoucoumaro

item.description: Toccato is a 3-D abstract game that uses 12 poly-forms that can be made into a cube. Players must place and remove the stones to score in specific patterns.

Felsberger Arena is a fast-action dexterity game played on a hexagonal board. Players flick marbles into the center felted play area to score points and knock opponents' marbles out. Made to the same high quality standards as the rest of the Felsberger lineup.

Riegel, which was designed by Paul Schobesberger (Austria), is an abstract game played on wooden board with 10 rows of sliders. Each row has depressions to hold marbles. Each player is trying to get their set of marbles from one side of the board to the other, but can only move onto certain depressions and thus the sliders must be positioned properly for movement. Made by Felsberger in the same high quality as their other games.

It is not an abstract strategy game since the moves are decided by dice according to http://toy-net.ch/felsberger/spielregeln/riegel.htm .

Felsberger Nuggets in an abstract game made in the same high quality wooden format as the rest of the Felsberger lineup. The game uses four colored turntables each housing up to four marbles, and players must rotate the turntables to make color matches to remove the marbles.

The Felsberger Labyrinth is a beautifully made game that plays very well. The high-quality board houses a set of movable channels and, as expected, the goal is to get the ball to flow the way you want it to. The board sits on a stand that allows it to tilt in any direction.

Hamertjesspel (Dutch for "The Little Mallet Game") is a traditional pub-game that was popular in the Low Lands of Belgium and the Netherlands and can be traced back as far as 1750. It could be regarded as an early form of Pinball, but despite its erstwhile popularity, it was all but forgotten in the latter half of the 20th century. Recently replica boards are making a bit of a comeback, and "het Hamertjesspel" can be seen again at village fêtes and other occasions that encourage nostalgic throw-back entertainment.

Four players sit on each side of a square wooden board with raised edges, defending their goal. A marble or small lead ball is dropped in the centre, either by hand or, on the more evolved board versions, through a "fair" central dropping device. Players try to get the marble into an opponent's goal, and keep their own one safe, by using a small wooden mallet ("Hamer" is Dutch for "Hammer"). To make life difficult for the players, the goal is split up in two by a centre isle, and spanned by a rail, so that it is impossible to block both halves simultaneously, or swap the hammer between goal sides easily. The board itself has a few obstacles (usually exposed nails) that deflect the marble. Game play is best typified as frantic fun.

The boards tend to have a slight slope towards the centre point. The square versions commonly use 4 wood sections in a pyramid style. The "Karrewiel" (Cart Wheel), which is the round board version usually had more panes to create a nicer circular slope. Occasionally it would also be able to accommodate more than the standard 4 players, or have each player's goal area split in three gaps, rather than two. Most boards would have only one marble in play, but, reportedly, there are variants that had multiple balls simultaneously in the battle arena. If less people were playing, parts of the board could be blocked off using temporary wooden walls.

Traditionally, the first player to lose a certain amount of goals would have to buy the next round. Like all pub games, it was also played for money, and onlookers placed bets on the game's outcome.

In 1995 Battle Dome appeared, which is a modern flipper version of this traditional game, with a few added bells and whistles. In 2000 Felsburger produced the traditional Karrewiel version under the name Chüngel. Needless to say, most versions of the game keep coming from the Low Lands wood crafts cottage industry, that is slowly "rediscovering" this lost gem. And since the dimensions have never been standardised, quality and appearance are as diverse as the woodworkers making them.
50 different Sudoku challenges. Three different ways to play: Standard, Challenge and Solitaire Sudoku.

Hab Acht ("Pay Attention") is a interesting memory variant, because it's motifs are printed on both sides of the tiles! There are 9 motifs printed on 36 tiles. Each front has a different backside, which means that every possible front/back-side is included in this game. Each motif is also printed on 9 task-tiles and every player draws 1 task-tile before the game begins.

Object of the game is to reveal all 8 motifs which match the task-tile. This can be quite difficult, especially, when you not also try to find "your" 8 motifs, but when you simultaneously try to inhibit certain motifs to come up, which apparently are being sought after from some of your opponents...

item.description: Glückstreffer ("Lucky Strike") is a Yahtzee variant, which makes use not only of usual dice numbers, but also of the colors they show. Every dice is printed with 1 red, blue, yellow and green side plus 2 sides in black. Accordingly, there are 6 dice used instead of the normal 5, so that it's possible to throw a row from 1-6 in every color.

The wife of the French President is found dead in her room. Who killed her?

All players (6 male, 3 female (+ 1 m/f)) should act out their roles to solve the mystery, because one of the guests is the murderer.

A computer shop-owner was found in his shop in a pool of blood. Who is the murder from the street party?

All players (4 male, 5 female (+ 1 m/f)) should act out their roles to solve the mystery, because one of the guests is the murderer.

One soccer star is kidnapped, and the kidnapper has killed people as well. Who hates Soccer enough to do this at the World Cup?

All players (5 male, 6 female (+ 1 m/f)) should act out their roles to solve the mystery, because one of the guests is the murderer

Frida has her birthday party, and her sister gets sick and goes to the bathroom. When they check on her later, she's found in a pool of blood. What's happening here?

All players (9 male, 3 female (+ 1 m/f)) should act out their roles to solve the mystery, because one of the guests is the murderer.

Jürgen and Colette are getting married today, but just before the ceremony Colette disappears. Where is she?

All players (4 male, 4 female (+ 1 m/f)) should act out their roles to solve the mystery, because one of the guests is the murderer.

Frank Mohn was found dead in this room. Who of the other hotel gusts knows more that the others?

All players (7 male, 4 female (+ 1 m/f)) should act out their roles to solve the mystery, because one of the guests is the murderer

"the every which way word game" (tm)

Players compete to score the most points by forming interlocking words in all directions, using square letter tiles, most of which can be used in more than one direction or as more than one letter.

WIM consists of 96 letter tiles, tile racks, and a letter bag. There is no board.

There are 19 distinct tiles which make the 26 letters plus the blank tile. Eight of the tiles are ambiguous and can be read as two different letters, depending on orientation. For example, an upside-down A is a V, and a sideways N is a Z. Three of the tiles may be used as the same letter in more than one orientation (O, S, and X). A tile may be used as different letters in different words at the same time, even in the same play.

Each letter has a different value and scores are calculated according to the letter played. Players receive bonuses for using a previously-played tile as a letter it wasn't used as previously, for changing the orientation of a word, or for using all seven tiles on their rack in a single play.

Home Page: http://www.puzzazz.com/wim

This is a simplified version of Proverbial Wisdom. There are three types of challenges for players: try to sketching, acting or define a saying. Comes with a spinner, card tray with sketch cards, picture cards and definition cards, clue hider, timer and sketch board. The first team to collect three of each card type wins.

name.value: Seven Horses of the Redfly Sacred Circle

item.description: This unique product will help your child to develop a respect for and understanding of Native American life. Contents include a carrying pouch, seven horses of the RedFly Sacred Circle game, colored paper, twelve star stones, one medicine wheel, numerical playing cards, instruction sheet and other pieces. Collect one of each colored teepee place cards as you travel around the Red Fly Sacred Circle. It is a cooperative game. The game is completed as a team effort with all players participating. The game ends when the last star stone is placed.

Players move their toads around the lily pond catching flies based on matching a color and a number on the spinner to the same color and number on the lily pads. Analytical thinking skills are used when players control the bumblebee and get to consider different possible places to put the bee and what consequence each possible choice might have. This game includes six toads, 36 flies, one bee, and a board with two spinners, game board showing pond with lily pads, SPLASH spots and logs.

The field is laid out on a 30 by 21 grid. Play alternates between the Offense and the Defense. The ball is advanced by passing dribbling and heading. When a defensive man is within specific distances from the ball and attempt can be made to tackle or intercept. The result is determined by throwing a die, but strategic placement of the men can affect the odds. Goal tries are similarly determined by die throws adjusted to the positioning of the goalkeeper and other defensive players.

From Designer's Notes:
KICK-OFF Soccer has been developed to follow as closely as possible the real game of soccer. The strategy and tactics are the same, as are most of the rules. Soccer is not a complicated game. There are very few set plays, these mainly arise on Corners, Free-Kicks and Throw-Ins. The game is played through with the skills, flair and innovation of individual players working together as a team. And so with "KICK-OFF", by using simple Basic Moves, the flair and innovation has been left up to the individual player.
After playing one or two games of "KICK-OFF", the method of play becomes easy and only brief reference is necessary to player and ball movement, and die throws. The die throws do not determine the outcome of the game, they merely simulate the chances played in real soccer.
"KICK-OFF" has been play tested by enthusiastic "youngsters" aged from eleven to adult. For the young enthusiasts, some adult assistance was found advisable at first, but once advised, they were at home with "KICK-OFF" as they were on the real field!

Tara is the newest Felsberger game and follows in their tradition of well-made wooden dexterity games. The games uses a color-sided die used to select pieces that are manipulated on the playing surface. A blend of strategy and dexterity.

Set in Classical Athens, players bid against each other to acquire the biggest and best collection of vases, as they travel round the key areas of the city. Good judgment and a pinch of luck are needed, but even then the gods of Mount Olympus may intervene to help or hinder you. [Taken from the game's website.]

item.description: A multi-player game based on the popular Sudoku puzzles. Players roll dice to show which numbers can be placed on the common grid. Numbers must be placed within legal Sudoku guidelines. Cards are used to re-arrange tiles and force other events. Players score each time they can complete a row, column, or box. A variant allows players to identify if a placement would cause the puzzle to become unsolvable.

Enter a Mysterious Land of 3D Adventure!
In the middle of a lake deep in a jungle, a centuries-old Idol sits atop an ancient tower. It’s a race to see who will be the first player to build a path across the lake and up the tower, seize the priceless Idol and escape to a waiting boat. But dangers lurk on every turn -- your opponent might block your escape route or steal the Idol from you -- or even bury your Explorer under a stone block!

The Strategy Game of Capture and Escape 
Using a team of Explorers and an array of action cards, place blocks across the lake to create a 3D path to the top of the tower. With each roll of the die, your Explorers get closer to the Idol. If you draw the right card, you can leap ahead of the other players, steal an opponent’s card or send a player back to the start. But the game can change in a heartbeat -– your Explorers might be stranded on the shore or buried beneath a block -- so every move requires strategy and planning.

The first player to reach the top of the tower, capture the Idol and escape to a waiting boat wins.

Idol QuestTM is fast-paced fun for the entire family!

item.description:
The game has 4 sets of 20 thick wooden tiles in 4 colors, which are numbered from 1-20. The 4x5 fields of the board also show the numbers 1-20.

Object of the game is to score the most points, but these points are given at the end of the game only! The game ends when all 80 tiles are placed on the board, but only the top tiles are valued; adjacent tiles of the same color give bonus points.

To reduce the influence of luck, the hand of 10 tiles is not filled randomly, but can be taken from 10 open tiles. Anyway, it's a game where you need a good memory, because you should remember which tiles have been played already and thus can't help you getting some bonus points.

This game is very easy to learn and play, but it's not so easy to find the best strategy.

snip from introduction:
" The Draw-Place deck face down in center of table. Each player draws one card at a time. First one to draw a dynamite card is the dealer.

The Deal-The cars are dealt one at a time beginning at left. With two players, deal seven cards to each. After all hands are dealt, dealer turns up the top card and leaves the deck face down beside it.

Object of Play-To get rid of all cards in your hand. the first player to succeed wins that round and the others must record their score according to the cards left in their hand."

As the name implies, their are rock, scissors, and paper cards. In addition, there are dynamite and double take cards, all of which come in assorted colors.

The short of it is, think Rock Scissors Paper meets Uno.

From the box:
Busy Busy Builder is a dress-up game for boys and girls who love building things! Be the busiest builder in town by collecting your own matching colored set of tools: screwdriver, hammer, wrench, nut and bolt. Don't work too fast because you might land on a Sore thumb. the first player to collect all of his or her tools and the Tool Belt wins the game.

Contents:
4 Moving bolts
4 Screwdrivers
4 Hammers
4 Wrenches
4 Nuts
4 Bolts
1 Sore thumb
1 Screwdriver spinner arrow
1 Tool Belt
1 Game Board
Instructions

Ages 3+

item.description: Twisted Fish is a variant of Go Fish. Instead of pairs, however, players are attempting to get groups of five - and memory plays a much larger aspect to the game, as well as a bit of bluffing. A few special cards are thrown into the mix to shake things up.

Three-Player Crokinole is a specially designed Crokinole board that works only with three. This game cannot be played on a standard board and thus is considered to be a different game.

The three-player board has markings that divide the board into three areas (vs four for a standard board), and repositions the pegs around the center to make these three positions optimal for shooting. Three players play independently (no partners), and when shooting either other player's disk must be hit for your shot to be legal. Scoring is done on a differences basis as in the original game, except often two people will score per turn as a result.

item.description:
Five-Hole Crokinole is played on a specially-drilled board and was popular in Canada in the late 1800s. The board is sized like a standard board, but in addition to the center hole it has a hole in the center of each 10-point area.

Play is similar to standard Crokinole, except that any disk pocketed in one of the 10-point area holes is removed from play and counts -10 points. This allows for both offensive attack and makes tricky shots more risky. As a result, scoring is usually more chaotic and variable.

This game can be bought in five-hole form, or often a standard board can be retrofitted to make this version. That retrofit is almost always one-way, though!

Viking Waves takes place in the areas raided and conquered by the Norwegian and Danish Vikings during the early Viking Age. It's a game primarily for two players, though limited solitaire play is also possible. The various Viking chieftains rarely fought each other directly, so players compete indirectly.

The game is divided into three phases, each of which involves dozens of raids/attacks and which can be played as a separate game (or all three can be played sequentially as a campaign). In Phase 1, which lasts from 792 until around 834, each raid involves a few ships and lasts only a few days. In Phase 2, from around 834 to around 850–864, raids are larger. In Phase 3, from around 850–864 until 879, the goal is conquering land with armies and creating permanent settlements.

In the standard game, each player represents an ever-changing group of Norwegian and Danish chieftains. Optional rules allow for the historical division of territory between Norwegian and Danish groups, allow for limited combat between the two players, and provide for solitaire play.

One twelve-page rulebook
Two 8.5" x 11" maps
One Player Display
342 counters

Players try to guess the word after they given a cryptic clue and the Inword, a series of consecutive letters within the word they are trying to guess. In turn, each player tries to guess the other letters contained in the target word. Players take turns as guessers and host.

A set of giant dice are rolled and depending on the type of arithmetic operations allowed in the game, players do math involving the numbers to match corresponding numbers on their sheet. The first player to get a row of 4 or 5 numbers wins.

item.description:
Jutland: 2 Player Card Game sim of the great Sea Battle of WWI. German vs British Fleets. Each side gets a Unique deck. Played in 6 "Historical" turns. Players try to get the highest scoring hand each turn. Good Filler game. Complete Ruleset and Cardset at: 
http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/Jutland.html

Oscar the Grouch, Cookie Monster, and Ernie face off in this slightly atypical memory matching game. Each player's goal is to have the longest chain of tiles at game end.

There are two notable differences from most memory matching games. 
1. Rather than two tiles being matched to each other, this game has players matching tiles to the symbol resulting from a spinner
2. Instead of ending when all tiles are matched, the game ends when the fourth stop tile is drawn.

Twenty-nine tiles are laid face-down on the play surface. These tiles interlock like puzzle pieces, making a chain of tiles when credited to a player. The game includes a spinner with, six spaces. Three of the spinner spaces show one shape (triangle, circle, or square), while the other three spaces have two shapes. Players take turns using the spinner, and then selecting one tile.

If the tile says "free spin", then the tile is added to that player's chain, and the player immediately takes an additional turn.

If the tile matches the shape(s) on the spinner, then the tile is added to the player's chain of tiles, and that player's turn ends.

If the tile does not match the shape on the spinner, the tile is shown to the other players, and then returned face-down to the available tiles.

If the tile says "stop", then it is attached to the top of the spinner. When the fourth "stop" tile is drawn, the game ends.

H.J.R. Murray's classic work on the history of chess includes chess variants from around the world and throughout history.

Originally published in 1913, it was recently reprinted and is now available again.

Contains history, development and the rules of nearly every Chess variant prior to 1900. A Classic!

Republished by Oxford University Press (available from Amazon et al)

Sesame Street Dominoes is played like the classic game Dominoes with variations for ages 3 and up and ages 4 and up. The dominoes are thick cardboard pieces with the faces of popular Sesame Street characters in the center surrounded by 4 different colors to the top, bottom, left and right.

In the 3 and up game, players match the faces of Sesame Street characters. In the 4 and up game, players match colors.

There's something rotten in the woods tonight - and it ain't your franks and beans! The dead are on the move, and it's up to you to put a stop to it. So grab your shotgun, fire up the chainsaw and get ready for some good old-fashioned zombie-hunting... Horror Rules style!

Horror Rules Mini-Games provide all the fun and mayhem of Horror Rules without the rule crunching. Included in this Mini-Game is everything you need to play, including Paper Forge Minis, maps, weapons and item counters and more - just print and go. Use the more than 60 Horror Markers to simulate the challenges, dangers, perils and scares of the zombie-infested woods, and change the mix to make a different game every time. You pick the size, scope, number of pieces and even the goal of each game.

The Horror Rules Mini-Game system is flexible and fully customizable, great for veteran gamers, kids, families, parties or as a way to introduce new players to the wonders of gaming. Play it solo or with others in cooperative or head-to-head play. Games take as little as 5 minutes and can easily be played during a coffee break or lunch time. With endless variations and Styles of Play, you can create whatever gaming environment you like, from a simple tabletop boardgame to a full-blown RPG.

Rotten Wood is packed with full-color gaming aids that bring the zombie nightmare alive. Inside you'll find:


 Paper Forge Character Minis: 6 complete Characters, each with Stats and Skills



 Paper Forge Bad Guy Minis: a full page of fearsome zombies, complete with Stats and Powers



 Map of Rotten Wood: 8 pages of maps; use them alone or together to build a master map



 Horror Markers: More than 60 counters packed with challenges, hazards, weapons, items, perils and frights



 Rule Spins: A dozen Spin cards to add endless variation and spice to your Mini-Game



 Bad Guy Power-Ups: Jack up your Bad Guys with these disgusting but guaranteed-to-please boosters



 Rules: All the instructions you need to make the mayhem happen


Paper Forge Character and Bad Guy Minis are fully compatible with Horror Rules the RPG, with Stats and Skills printed right on the back. Use them to play the Mini-Game, the full RPG or any other modern roleplaying game. The 8-pg map can be used in HR as well or whatever game you choose.

Included in this download are two complete sets of rules, enough to fit every taste:

The Basic Rules are a quick, simple board game with fast setup, plenty of action and thrills and tremendous variation. Use the Horror Markers to make every game exciting and different. Play by yourself or with a pal.

The Skirmish Rules are full-out tabletop war. Pit your heroic and resourceful characters against the not-so-heroic and ravenous zombies in a knock-down drag-out no-holds-barred free-for-all in Rotten Wood. Skirmish Markers include standard Horror Rules weapons with full Horror Rules stats. Requires two to play.

"Find out how to identify the birds in YOUR garden!"

In this game, players move around the board collecting points by correctly identifying and answering questions about wild birds that might be found in British gardens. Although prior knowledge helps, it's not essential: the game is designed to help players develop their bird-related expertise.

"RACECRAZE: A Strategic, Fun-Filled Racing Game!"

A Nascar-like themed racing game from a small publisher. The mechanics of this game are simple: "Qualifying" position is based on random card draw. Each turn, roll three (standard) dice, and optionally roll two more "special dice" (33% +3, 33% -3, 33% take a card). Move your car on the track (16 spaces to 20 spaces around from inside to outside track; no track "choke points") by the total amount. Cards either move car forward, backward, or force player "into the pit" before proceeding. Player turn order is re-ranked each turn by position+laps, and each race (of 5) ends after a predetermined number of laps.

Each player is awarded a number of points at the conclusion of each race based on finishing position. Winner has the most points after the fifth race.

item.description: Two player card game. Simulates a battle between two tank formations during WW2. The current version of the game has decks for: Germans, British, and Americans circa 1944-5. Rules and card set available at: http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/TanK.html
High Iron is a very early Winsome game with an extremely limited print run. It is Colorado-based train game with idea that were further and better developed in later Winsome titles.
GAMETASIA CARDS 71 boxed cards featuring 47 Extractors, 9 Utopians, 9 Treasure Cards, and 6 Rules Cards. 2 to 4 players.

Royal Poker Dice Game is a game of Yahtzee using the entire deck of cards.
Five 12-sided dice use all 52 cards of a normal deck plus 8 stars (wild cards). Every possible poker hand can be made.
For one or more players.

Contents: Five 12 sided Dice, Dice Cup, Score Pad, Felt Mat, Convenient Carry Case.

A less expensive "travel" version is available which eliminates the felt mat, changes the shape of the dice cup to oblong, and replaces the carry case with a fabric drawstring bag.

Two containers hold 25 3 dimensional one-inch cubes each. The cubes have pictures numbered 1-5 on all of their sides except one, which holds a large red X on it.

The object of the game is to to acquire five X's in a row, like a bingo game. However, this game is much more complex in its variant forms.

Initially, the base setup is for each person to turn all of their picture cubes to the 1 numbered picture--the easiest items to spot. Goal: Spot five items or a picture of each of the five items, revealing 5 X's which form a straight line.

Rise To The Top: In this variant, each person does not reveal the X upon sighting a 1 numbered item. Instead, the person will turn the number two picture to the top. This continues until the number three item is sighted, and the X is turned up. The first person to five X's in a row wins.

Go For Points: Similar to Above. Attach a time limit or mileage limit to the game. At game end, total the numbers of the photos as points, scoring each X as a 10 point item. Highest total wins.

This can be played as a solo variant, with a solo player trying to accomplish point goals per number of miles, or trip duration.

The Handicapper: In a child versus adult game, using the base game rules, the adult would adjust their numbered pictures to a 4 or 5 starting point.

One Block At A Time: Start with all X's showing. Each person will take out the first block in their container. As soon as either player sees one of the five items, they replace the block in their container with the picture showing of the item spotted. They then move on to their next block, until all 25 blocks are gone through.

The game ends when one person is done with all 25 blocks. Total all points of exposed pictures.

Get Nasty: Each player arranges the cubes of their opponent, using the number five pictures of each number (5-5's, 5'4's, etc...) and arranges them in a way which is thought to be most difficult to achieve 5 in a row. Same as base game otherwise.

Composite Game: Start with all number 1's. As you see each item, turn that cube over to X. When you get five X's in a row, turn that row over to the number two pictures. Continue with the same goals, turning five in a row over at a time until you get the five numbered pictures. The first person to turn over five number five pictures, revealing the final X's, wins. A complicated variant, indeed.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

name.value: El gran juego de Conocer la Ciencia

item.description:
A Spanish Trivial pursuit clone, Science themed.
The 5 categories are:
 - Nature
 - Space & Technology
 - Characters
 - Science history
 - Other Sciences

This is a game for 2 to 4 players. The instructions say that it should be played by girls and boys together. Each player gets a particular color to start on. That color is used later on. A girl starts the game! There are spaces on the gameboard such as First Class, Air Mail or Special Delivery. When a player lands on one of them the player picks a card and reads it aloud. The card will list some kind of stunt that must be accomplished in order to score points. If a partner is needed to accomplish the stunt then the player spins a spinner, the male who has that color representing him is the girls partner for the stunt. There is a time limit to accomplish each stunt. The stunts are childish (this game is appropriate for perhaps 8 to 12 year olds). Some examples of stunts that need to be done; You and your partner eat a potato chip at the same time and immediately whistle Yankee Doodle. First one to whistle the first line wins the points. Or Standing back to back with your partner, remove his or her jacket or sweater and put it on yourself without turning around. The successful completion of a stunt in the given time limit results in winning a certain amount of points. First player to reach 500 points is the winner.

This is a game about Skipper (Barbie's younger sister) and her horse Prince. Appropriate for 6 to 10 year olds. It is a simple roll and move game. The object of the game is to be the person who reaches the BEST IN SHOW square at the center of the board while holding; a card for your horse Prince, your tack, your riding habit, your club pin and 25 points . Players roll and move around the board. On some spots on the board you will be given the opportunity to enter the SHOW RING and score points for how your horse does. Those points can be traded in for some of what you need. Necessary money is accumulated as you go around the squares on the board.

Spion (=Spy) is a 2-player strategy game with an unusual victory condition: you must find two hidden points on the opponents half of the gameboard. These hidden points are secretly marked on a paper copy of the gameboard; a whole pad of copies is included.

The gameboard has 2 halves of 64 hex-fields each and the armies of the 2 players contain 6 defenders, 4 little spies and 2 big spies. The defenders are single colored, while the spies show both colors, because they can be turned over when captured! Defenders cannot leave their half of the board. Spies can move everywhere and they are therefore needed to find the 2 hidden points.
